description: Weve literally had some continue using drugs while in the hospital. Thats like trying to do a liver transplant on someone whos drinking a fifth of vodka on the stretcher.

title: No Corrections: April 30, 2018
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 30, 2018.

title: Billions Season 3, Episode 6 Recap: Eat or Be Eaten
description: If theres one place where we can come together in these divided times, surely its to appreciate a show that gives us opening scenes like the one this week: Axe and Wags, sitting at a table with cloth napkins draped over their heads, faces obscured, for two reasons, as Wags puts it: to keep the aromas from escaping, and to hide this shameful and depraved act from God.

title: Sajid Javid Is Named U.K. Home Secretary, Replacing Amber Rudd
description: LONDON  Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain moved swiftly to replace Amber Rudd as home secretary on Monday, promoting Sajid Javid, a son of Pakistani immigrants, in a move that made him the first nonwhite politician to hold one of the most senior British cabinet positions.

title: Trust Season 1, Episode 6 Recap: A Dead Body Focuses the Mind
description: So far, Trust has shown us that J. Paul Getty Sr. is not exactly what youd call good with people, but his instincts for business are spot on. In this weeks episode, however, those instincts are called into question for the first time. In the final moments of the previous episode, we dont know if little Paul has survived Primos raid at the peaceful farmhouse, when Primo shoots Angelo in the face, and we hear a second shot go off before the episode cuts to black. For about half of this episode, the Gettys believe that Paul Sr.s paltry counteroffer to the kidnappers $17 million demand was a tragic miscalculation  that, for once, Gettys outsized confidence in his business acumen has misled him, only this time the cost was not a barrel of oil but his grandsons life.

title: Ronny Jackson, Failed V.A. Pick, Is Unlikely to Return as Trumps Doctor
description: WASHINGTON  Dr. Ronny L. Jackson, who withdrew from consideration for secretary of veterans affairs last week amid allegations related to his professional conduct, is unlikely to return to his role as the presidents doctor, according to a person familiar with the matter.

title: Britain, Pamplona, Killer Caterpillars: Your Monday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: How Your Brain Can Trick You Into Trusting People
description: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. Editor Tim Herrera emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

title: A Polyglot N.B.A. Swears by One Thing: That Call Was #@!&
description: Enes Kanter of the Knicks wants to make it clear that he no longer swears  in any language. But back when he did, at the start of his N.B.A. career in 2011, he swore exclusively in Turkish. He went his entire first season without referees calling him on it.

title: After Chaos, Port Authority Sets Storm Rules for Planes to Kennedy
description: Airlines will be prohibited from sending planes to Kennedy Airport during winter storms, like the one that caused chaos there in January, unless they have received assurances that gates will be available on landing.

title: Gary Sanchezs Homer Gives Yankees a 9th Straight Win
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  A towering home run by Gary Sanchez, a throwback pitching performance by C.C. Sabathia and some tense relief work by Chad Green and Aroldis Chapman were enough to carry the Yankees to a 2-1 victory over the Los Angeles Angels on Sunday night at Angel Stadium.

title: A Day at the Movies in Saudi Arabia
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  I learned to love movies in a country where cinemas were illegal. My only access to film as a Saudi girl came through our crummy local video shop in suburban Riyadh where I grew up, where women were forbidden to enter. When I was old enough to go on my own, I would wait just outside the door for a male worker to bring me a catalog to flip through, selecting titles that would transport me to places that seemed millions of miles away.

title: Whats on TV Monday: James Camerons Story of Science Fiction and Elementary
description: James Cameron gathers fellow sci-fi buffs to explore the genres history in a new AMC series. And the eccentric Sherlock Holmes of Elementary returns for Season 6.

title: A Week Inside a Soccer Club When the Money Runs Out
description: KONGENS LYNGBY, Denmark  Mads Byder sent the text message to everyone he could think of, anyone who had the money  and maybe the madness  to help. In the end, he copied and pasted the message 15 times, changing the name of the recipient, but nothing else.

title: South Korea to End Propaganda Broadcasts Along Border With North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea said on Monday that it would begin this week to dismantle the loudspeakers that have broadcast propaganda across the border into North Korea for decades, the first step toward implementing an agreement the countrys leaders reached during their summit meeting on Friday.

title: Detroit Was Crumbling. Heres How Its Reviving.
description: Last week, we visited the city to find further signs of recovery as Detroit moves out from under budgetary oversight.

title: Journalists Suffer Deadliest Day in Afghanistan Since at Least 2002
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Twin bombings in Kabul on Monday killed at least 25 people, including nine journalists. It was the deadliest single attack involving journalists in Afghanistan since at least 2002, and one of the most lethal ever worldwide, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists.

title: A Numbers Guy Left the Front Office to Coach Prospects. Heres What He Learned.
description: Sig Mejdal has an opinion on baseball players. It might seem radical, but hes a smart man, a former NASA researcher at the forefront of baseballs statistical revolution. Let him explain.

title: Fearing Death, and Photographing the Rituals That Surround It
description: The question of what awaits after death has obsessed humanity for millennia.

title: Worried About Risky Teenage Behavior? Make School Tougher
description: Like all parents of teenagers, I worry that my children will engage in risky behavior, including drinking, smoking and drug use. The more time they spend doing healthier extracurricular activities  soccer, piano, cleaning their rooms (ha!)  the better.

title: A Book of Emails Women Love to Hate
description: It sounds simple, even innocuous, as greetings go.

title: #GorsuchStyle Garners a Gusher of Groans. But Is His Writing Really That Bad?
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Neil M. Gorsuch arrived at the Supreme Court last year with a reputation as a fine writer. He promptly lost it.

title: Anonymous Owner, L.L.C.: Why It Has Become So Easy to Hide in the Housing Market
description: When Sean Hannity, the popular Fox News host, was revealed this month to be a property owner and landlord of considerable scale, it highlighted how opaque the housing market has become.

title: When the Downstairs Neighbors Become Best Friends
description: When Zach Tan Strein, Corey Eisenberg and Alex Faoro signed the lease on a three-bedroom apartment on the border of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick, Brooklyn, last June, they didnt give much thought to who their downstairs neighbors would be.

title: See the Sights in the Southwest and California Like a Rock Star
description: The kind of tricked-out buses associated with rock-star tours will drive a new kind of road trip with the launch of the travel company Roadies.

title: How Would a T-Mobile-Sprint Merger Affect Your Cellphone Bill?
description: WASHINGTON  T-Mobiles proposed merger with Sprint would create a new national wireless giant capable of taking on Verizon and AT&T. The combined company, which would be called T-Mobile, would cover about 100 million customers.

title: They Survived a Massacre. Then the Lawyers Started Calling.
description: It was late one night in February when a barrage of Facebook messages started lighting up Christopher Hansens phone. Each one included an image of a stranger whose life had been upended by a mass shooting. Just like Mr. Hansens.

title: Americas Most Famous Street
description: BROADWAY A History of New York City in Thirteen Miles By Fran Leadon Illustrated. 512 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $35.

title: The First Lady of the Confederacy Considers Her Painful Past
description: VARINA By Charles Frazier 356 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $27.99.

title: The Duplass Brothers: The First Time We Got Cable TV
description: It is dark. It is late. It is 1984.

title: Celebrate! 9 European Festivals Worth Traveling For
description: From Spain to Macedonia, celebrating food, flowers, seasons and traditions.

title: Missile Attack in Syria Reportedly Kills at Least 16, Raising Regional Tensions
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The missiles struck after dark, hitting facilities in Syria where Iran and its militant proxies had set up camp, setting buildings on fire and causing an explosion so large that it shook the ground like a minor earthquake.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | April 30, 2018
description: Updated: May 3, 2018

title: North Korea, Sprint, Michelle Wolf: Your Monday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: How Much Do You Know About Canada?
description: Can you find Canada on a map? What else do you know about this North American nation with 36 million people?

title: Sex and Shame: What Incels and Jihadists Have in Common
description: As an instrument for delivering publicity, terrorism clearly works. Or at least it did last week, when the hitherto obscure term incel went viral after Alek Minassian drove a truck into a crowd of pedestrians in downtown Toronto. Mr. Minassian, just before carrying out his attack, wrote a post on Facebook in which he proclaimed the arrival of an incel rebellion. Standing for involuntarily celibate, the term is used as a badge of honor among a fringe online subculture of misogynists who say they hate women for depriving them of sex. So now we know.

title: Happy Birthday, Karl Marx. You Were Right!
description: SEOUL, South Korea  On May 5, 1818, in the southern German town of Trier, in the picturesque wine-growing region of the Moselle Valley, Karl Marx was born. At the time Trier was one-tenth the size it is today, with a population of around 12,000. According to one of Marxs recent biographers, Jrgen Neffe, Trier is one of those towns where although everyone doesnt know everyone, many know a lot about many.

title: Nature Is Risky. Thats Why Students Need It.
description: Nature is unscripted and hard to predict. Having recently discovered this reality, Penn State has decided that its 98-year-old, student-led Outing Club shall no longer be allowed to go on outings. Citing the high risk of remote environments and poor cellphone service, the university is recommending that the club restrict its offerings to films and speakers. Students are being funneled into engaging only in previously vetted human constructions.

title: Listen to The Daily: A Family Divided by the Korean War
description: A peace treaty between North and South Korea could bring reunions for the thousands of families who have been separated for more than six decades.

title: Listen to The Daily: A Family Divided by the Korean War
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: On Being an Orphan, Frequently
description: To my great and continuing surprise, I am an orphan. Another way of saying that would just be that I am no longer remotely young, that I am the mother of grown children, that at my next college reunion there will be some classmates who are already talking retirement. People my age have parents in their 80s and 90s, if they have parents at all.

title: Alzheimers? Your Paperwork May Not Be in Order
description: I had hoped that by now most adults in this country would have completed an advance directive for medical care and assigned someone they trusted to represent their wishes if and when they are unable to speak for themselves. Alas, at last count, barely more than one-third have done so, with the rest of Americans leaving it up to the medical profession and ill-prepared family members to decide when and how to provide life-prolonging treatments.

title: New York Today: The Officers Checking Your Trash
description: Good morning on this luminous Monday.

title: Mike Pompeo Expresses Support for Israeli Response to Gaza Protests
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, speaking in Jordan at the end of a four-day, four-nation tour through the Middle East, expressed support on Monday for Israel and its response to weekly protests in Gaza that have left dozens of people dead.

title: Word + Quiz: vagabond
Do You Gamify Your Life?
description: If you are a student, you probably monitor your grades pretty closely. Do you also track other numbers-related aspects of your life, tracking things like sleeping a certain number of hours a night, taking a certain number of steps each day and other aspects of daily life?

title: Teaching Activities for: Kim Prepared to Cede Nuclear Weapons if U.S. Pledges Not to Invade
description: Before reading the article:

title: Yellow Fever Restaurant at California Whole Foods Sets Off a Debate
description: When an Asian restaurant named Yellow Fever opened more than four years ago in the unassuming Southern California suburb of Torrance, some people were perturbed but kept their opinions to themselves. After all, they thought, how much harm could a single fast-casual restaurant do in a strip mall?

title: China Is Set to Take a Hard Line on Trumps Trade Demands
description: BEIJING  Staking an assertive negotiating stance, China says it will refuse to discuss President Trumps two toughest trade demands when American officials arrive in Beijing this week, potentially derailing the high-level talks.

title: How the Sprint Deal is a Feather in T-Mobile C.E.O.s Cap: DealBook Briefing
description: Good Monday. Heres what were watching:

title: Trump vs. Justice
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

title: Pitch Behind T-Mobile-Sprint Merger: Keep Up With China in 5G
description: BEIJING  As tensions rise between the United States and China in the high-tech realm, even a merger of two American wireless providers has become entangled in fears about losing international competitiveness.

title: U.S. Embassy Officer in Pakistan Is Charged With Obstruction
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The police in Pakistan have charged a United States Embassy security officer with seeking to obstruct an investigation into a car accident involving an embassy vehicle, police officials said on Monday, adding to diplomatic tensions days after an American military attach was barred from leaving the country over a separate collision.

title: California Today: Can San Diego Ditch the Power Company?
description: Good morning.

title: A Trump Nobel Peace Prize? South Koreas Leader Likes the Idea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Several months ago, South Koreans considered President Trump as dangerous as North Koreas leader, Kim Jong-un, as the two traded threats of nuclear annihilation.

title: Why All the New Terms of Service?
description: Q. This week alone, Ive gotten several notifications from online services that I use about privacy policy updates. Is this because of the Facebook  flap?

title: Trump, Hoping for Great Celebration, Wants to Hold North Korea Talks in DMZ
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump on Monday fanned expectations for his meeting with Kim Jong-un, saying he would like his talks with the North Korean leader to take place at the Demilitarized Zone that separates the two Koreas because theres a great celebration to be had on the site if the negotiations are successful.

title: Westworld: What Was the Deal With William and Dolores Again?
description: Coming just two episodes into a season that was nearly 17 months in the making, Dolores and Williams reunion in this weeks episode of Westworld was bound to prompt some questions. For starters, is fair to call it a reunion when it happens in flashbacks? More important: What, exactly, was their deal again?

title: Doping Whistleblower Sues Russian Olympians and Their Oligarch Backer, an N.B.A. Owner
description: Grigory Rodchenkov, Russias former antidoping lab chief who in 2016 publicly detailed the nations Olympic doping schemes and upended Russias standing in international sports, responded to a defamation suit on Monday, countersuing several Russian Olympians and taking aim at the oligarch who is partly financing their legal fight: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the controlling owner of the N.B.A.s Brooklyn Nets.

title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Good morning. Its an uncertain, difficult world we live in, sometimes hard to explain, and all the more so when you look around and its as if everyones mad at you, all the time, even when they say theyre not. Heres some nickel advice: Take a good long walk after you read The Times in the morning, however you read it, and then cook dinner at the end of the day, even if its just ramen from Sevs with a poached egg, scallions and a dusting of sesame seeds. Be active. Take care. Thats the ticket to ride.

title: Ink, a Tale of Rupert Murdochs Rise, Is Coming to Broadway
description: Ink, a new British play about the rise of Rupert Murdoch, will have its American premiere on Broadway next spring.

title: Maker to Know: A Ceramist Creating Insect-Adorned Plates
description: At an age when most kids spend their waking hours playing video games, the ceramist Marc Armitano Domingo  not yet in high school, and living in Northern California  was learning a 15th-century instrument and yearning to take Communion. I wished I was more Catholic. My older brothers had to go to Communion and I wanted to be cool like them, but my parents didnt make me. And so I begged them. I wanted to dress up in the little suits! says Armitano Domingo, now 21.

title: Wheelchairs Prohibited in the Last Place Youd Expect
description: In March 2017, a woman met with the admissions coordinator at Madison York Assisted Living in Queens, inquiring about placement for her mother-in-law, who was using a wheelchair while recovering from hip surgery.

title: An Unorthodox Design Gallery in a London Townhouse
description: From the outside, Nathalie Assis white-stucco house looks as grandly traditional as the others that line the quiet Kensington street where she lives with her husband and three children. This is one of Londons most venerable neighborhoods: Queen Victoria grew up around the corner in Kensington Palace, now home to Prince William and his young family. But inside Assis front door, stuffy convention comes abruptly to a stop.

title: Inside the Home Showroom of a London Design Pioneer
description: Nathalie Assi, founder of the design platform Seeds, lives among the unusual objects she commissions and exhibits.

title: What the Heck Is That?: ONAGER
description: SPECIAL POST  Its not often that a wild animal trips up New York Times crossword solvers to such an extent, but the ONAGER was the most-revealed answer in last Thursdays puzzle.

title: South Sudan Rebels Free 10 Aid Workers
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Ten aid workers detained in South Sudan last week have been freed after the rebel group holding them confirmed their identities as representatives of relief agencies, the rebels said on Monday.

title: How a Rose Blooms: Its Genome Reveals the Traits for Scent and Color
description: The scent of a rose fades over time, and has for hundreds of years.

title: Cosby Jury Says Accusers Credibility, Not #MeToo, Led to Guilty Verdict
description: In a joint statement on Monday, the jurors who voted to convict Bill Cosby of sexual assault last week said that they believed his accusers account and were persuaded of his guilt by the facts, not the momentum of social change captured in the #MeToo movement.

title: Seen Avengers: Infinity War? Heres What to Read About That Shocking Ending
description: Avengers: Infinity War incinerated global box-office records over the weekend, taking in $630 million around the world. But the movies earnings are less surprising than its dark conclusion, which surely had fans from Chicago to China stumbling out of theaters with their mouths hanging open. (Read the Times review by A.O. Scott, here as well as his thoughts on the films ending.) If the latest developments in the Marvel Cinematic Universe left you puzzled, our roundup of what to read after youve seen Infinity War should clear up some confusion. Some spoilers lie ahead.

title: Tokyo in Texas: Distinctive Japanese Food Is Thriving in Austin
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Tyson Cole got hooked on the original Japanese version of Iron Chef in the early 1990s, after taking a job as a dishwasher and server at a sushi restaurant here in his adopted hometown.

title: A Haven in Queens for Flight Personnel After Touching Down
description: It was just after 10 on a Monday night  flight night at Austins Ale House in Kew Gardens, Queens  and the place was packed with flight attendants and pilots.

title: A Population That Pollutes Itself Into Extinction (and Its Not Us)
description: For simple single-celled organisms, microbes often can seem as civic-minded as an Amish barn-raising crew.

title: How to Make the Most of the Frieze Week Art Fairs
description: Spring weather has finally arrived in New York, and its just in time for the annual bonanza of contemporary art fairs. There are three art fairs running simultaneously this week in Manhattan and a bevy in Brooklyn, all of them vying for the attention of new collectors, as well as the veterans whose deep pockets make the whole art world spin.

title: Does the Ending of Avengers: Infinity War Spoil Itself?
description: The following piece discusses details from the ending of Avengers: Infinity War.

title: Michelle Wolf Did What Comedians Are Supposed to Do
description: Comedy has no rules, per se. But in my 15 years of writing and performing, Ive come up with a few guidelines that I find helpful:

title: Picking an Extra Aejo Tequila Takes Extra Care
description: Cinco de Mayo is not the moment for extra aejo tequila. While plenty of the agave spirit from Jalisco, Mexico, will flow on May 5, in cheap margaritas and shots, the bottles classified as extra aejo  which by Mexican law must be aged more than three years  will mostly stay on the top shelf of the bar, awaiting another day.

title: An Artist Who Leaves His Work Up to Nature  and Chance
description: Jitish Kallat, the Mumbai-based artist whose first show at New Yorks Sperone Westwater gallery opened last week, frequently uses unorthodox methods: He labors away in the rain at night, or douses drawings with inflammable liquids and sets them on fire.

title: Review: Dudamel and Los Angeles Bring the Noise to New York
description: What defines the Los Angeles Philharmonic? Is it the music and artistic director Gustavo Dudamels exciting performances of symphonies central to the repertory? Or is it the risks the orchestra takes on rarities and new pieces  including what feels like a Year of 1,000 Commissions for its centennial next season? (O.K., not quite that many. But its a lot.)

title: Photojournalist Killed in Kabul Left a Legacy of Images
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Through the dark days of the 1990s civil war and the Talibans oppressive rule, the Afghan photographer Shah Marai never left his country. As the bloodshed continued after the 2001 American-led invasion, he repeatedly expressed a feeling shared by so many Afghans caught in the devastating cycle: There is no more hope.

title: The Firing of the House Chaplain
description: To the Editor:

title: Did Michelle Wolfs Roast Go Too Far?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sake for Everyday Drinking
description: Masaharu Morimoto, the chef and restaurateur, wants to see more Japanese cooking at home in America. To his line of cookbooks, knives, grapeseed oils and beer, he has added sake. Sake is not easy to understand, he said. Im making it easy. His new sake for everyday drinking, Easy Cup, is a junmai premium sake made from highly polished rice by Gekkeikan, a centuries-old Japanese company. Its straightforward, mellow and somewhat floral, making it a fine starter sake and excellent to serve chilled with seafood. It comes in a convenient, picnic-ready resealable glass jar at a modest price: Easy Cup Sake, $19.99 for five 7.1-ounce jars, Grand Cru Wine & Spirits, 570 11th Avenue (43rd Street), 646-682-9278, grandcruny.com.

title: Judith Leiber, 97, Dies; Turned Handbags Into Objets dArt
description: Judith Leiber, the handbag designer whose whimsical creations were prized as collectors pieces and frequently displayed as objets dart, died on Saturday at her home in Springs, N.Y., a hamlet in East Hampton. She was 97.

title: Brooklyn Diner Makes Its Mustard Available to the Public
description: For that hot dog off the grill, ditch the pinky-up Dijon. Instead open a jar of New York-style mustard from the Brooklyn Diner restaurants. Its being sold retail for the first time. Called real Jewish mustard, not the yellow ballpark variety, its slightly grainy and vinegary, the better to slap back at fatty meats: Brooklyn Diner Real Jewish Mustard, $5 for nine ounces at Brooklyn Diner restaurants and from brooklyndiner.com.

title: The New Restaurant P.S.A. Poster: How to Deal With Sexual Harassment
description: Borrowing from the design of the standard Heimlich maneuver poster in restaurants, the magazine Cherry Bombe, which celebrates women in the culinary world, has produced a bold poster showing steps to take in the case of sexual harassment. Karen Leibowitz, a San Francisco restaurateur, came up with the idea and arranged for Kelli Anderson, a Brooklyn graphic artist, to design it: Sexual Harassment P.S.A. Poster, $10, or print at home, cherrybombe.com/86-this.

title: The Stealth Success of John Mulaney
description: John Mulaney was waiting to take the stage when the Saturday Night Live announcer declared, Ladies and gentlemen, John Mulvaney!

title: Grinding Out the Details of a Good Cup of Coffee
description: Coffee may not be rocket science, but despite the title, even a quick spin through this highly detailed volume suggests it might come close. Consider more than 30 pages just about espresso, best served in a china cup at least a quarter-inch thick. For most filter methods, a kettle with a gooseneck spout is essential. A coffee lover is sure to find plenty thats useful in this illustrated book, which is mostly about making the beverage properly. Coffee around the world, a coffee lexicon, production, equipment, grinding, storing, proportions and temperatures are all in there: Coffee Isnt Rocket Science: A Quick & Easy Guide to Buying, Brewing, Serving, Roasting & Tasting Coffee by Sbastien Racineux and Chung-Leng Tran (Black Dog & Leventhal, $24.99).

title: Founder of Jacobs Pickles Goes After the Dumpling Crowd
description: Jacob Hadjigeorgis first made his mark on the Upper West Side with pickles: Jacobs Pickles, then Maison Pickle. It was Maison Pickles best-selling shrimp pillow dumpling, an odd winner in a place that specializes in French dip sandwiches, that inspired his latest venture, combining pickles and dumplings. Im going with whats popular, he said. His new storefront, mostly for takeout, has six varieties of dumplings, with the delicate shrimp among them; three noodle dishes, including a meaty, modestly spicy dan dan; and, of course, pickles to order from a kiosk in the store, an app or online for pickup or delivery. Theres soft-serve in matcha and also a pickle flavor that suggests cucumber frozen yogurt: Lucky Pickle Dumpling Co., 513 Amsterdam Avenue (85th Street), 212-392-5407, luckypickledumpling.co.

title: Women Fighting Sexism in Jazz Have a Voice. And Now, a Code of Conduct.
description: Over the past year a steady stream of public testimonials from female jazz musicians has made clear what most already knew privately: Sexism and harassment are deeply ingrained in the improvised-music world.

title: Sullivan Street Bakery Gets a Makeover
description: Its been nearly 18 years since Jim Lahey moved his Italian-style Sullivan Street Bakery to West 47th Street from SoHo, keeping the name. During that time, hes tweaked the Hells Kitchen location more than once. Now, hes given it a complete overhaul and will open on Thursday, adding a bright new cafe and upgrading some of the equipment in the big wholesale bakery that may be hidden from view but is the soul of the operation. The menu for the light, airy cafe is the work of the corporate executive chef Morgan Schofield. It starts with breakfast items like brioche French toast and includes soups, salads, pastries and made-to-order or grab-and-go sandwiches. Theres a stretch of retail counter for breads, other baked goods, and Mr. Laheys signature Roman pizzas: Sullivan Street Bakery, 533 West 47th Street, 212-265-5580, sullivanstreetbakery.com.

title: Audible Brings Girls & Boys With Carey Mulligan to New York
description: Audible Inc. is continuing its move into the theater world by bringing the live stage production of Girls & Boys starring Carey Mulligan from the Royal Court Theater in London to the Minetta Lane Theater in New York.

title: J. Cole Hits No. 1 With KOD, Another Streaming Win for Rap
description: The streaming champions of modern hip-hop have not yet hit their ceiling.

title: Review: Becoming Who I Was Looks at a Boys Days, and His Past Lives
description: In my previous life, I used to live in Kham, Tibet, Padma Angdu, 9, says in Becoming Who I Was, and hes not the only one in his remote Indian village who believes that he is a rinpoche  a reincarnated centuries-old monk.

title: Michelle Wolf Did Her Job. Its the Correspondents Dinner That Is the Problem.
description: One of Michelle Wolfs first jokes at the White House Correspondents Association dinner involved a certain vulgarity that rode into widespread public use aboard Donald Trumps Access Hollywood bus. To this crowd, it was apparently still a bit shocking. You should have done more research before you got me to do this, she said.

title: To Make Someone Be or Not to Make Someone Be
description: The unnamed narrator of Motherhood, Sheila Hetis earthy and philosophical and essential new novel, is a writer in her late 30s. She smokes; shes divorced; she lives with her boyfriend in a Toronto apartment thats pretty but has mice in the walls.

title: Four Shows to Watch This Week
description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.

title: The Cost of Child Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: As Detroit Sheds State Oversight, Its Mayor Reflects on Its Path
description: For the first time in years, Detroit is in charge of its own budget. A Michigan commission assigned to oversee the citys financial decisions voted on Monday to end its day-to-day control.

title: Is Stacey Abrams Assembling a New Democratic Majority?
description: When early voting begins today in the Georgia primary campaign for governor, Stacey Abrams, the former minority leader of the Georgia House of Representatives, may very well take a momentous step closer to becoming the first black woman in the nation to be elected governor. Ms. Abrams will have entered that office lifted by the political power of a multiracial coalition led by the Democratic Partys most powerful voting bloc, black women.

title: N.F.L. Draft 7th Round: Where Rugby Players and Future Dentists Get Picked
description: Its the round for the good but not great, the project or the flyer. The seventh and final round of the N.F.L. draft doesnt unearth many superstars, but every once in a while it produces a gem, like Julian Edelman or Shannon Sharpe.

title: C.D.C. Directors $375,000 Salary Will Be Cut
description: The government will lower the $375,000 salary of the new director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Dr. Robert R. Redfield, after reports that he was being paid considerably more than previous directors, the Department of Health and Human Services confirmed on Monday, though it declined to say what his new pay will be.

title: Review: Big Is Beautiful Questions the Virtues of Small Business
description: One of the few remaining topics about which Americas increasingly polarized populace can seem to agree is the relative virtue of small business. Whether you are a Midwestern populist bemoaning the decline of the family farm, an East Coast realist focused on the role of small firms in driving job creation, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur dreaming of disrupting the status quo or just bitter that your favorite local restaurant was replaced by an Olive Garden, everyone, it seems, has reason to embrace small businesses. In the view of Robert D. Atkinson and Michael Lind, the authors of Big Is Beautiful: Debunking the Myth of Small Business, Americas predisposition since the 1970s for favoring the little guy is not just misguided but has had a profoundly pernicious effect on our economy and society.

title: As Oscars Pile Up, Iranian Film Grows Up
description: TEHRAN  As the veteran American director took the stage at Irans Fajr International Film Festival, the audience stood up, clapping and cheering.

title: Creepy or Not? Your Privacy Concerns Probably Reflect Your Politics
description: Are you creeped out by the idea of a company checking a job candidates credit history before deciding whether to hire her or him? Your answer could be tied to your political views.

title: California Is Ready for a Fight Over Tailpipe Emissions. Heres Why.
description: California officials have said they will fight in court any attempt by the Trump administration to revoke or bypass their power to set their own auto emissions standards. Here are three big issues for the state.

title: Parenting the Fortnite Addict
description: Every so often a game comes along that conquers the hearts, minds and thumbs of gamers everywhere. Fortnite: Battle Royale is the latest victor in this category. According to a  report last week from the market research firm SuperData, the game generated $223 million in March, and it begins a new season  with a new theme and a few other changes  on May 1.

title: Somehow the Least Scandalous Thing in D.C. This Weekend Was the Playboy Party
description: WASHINGTON  The first year of Donald Trumps presidency has featured a swirling, breathless national conversation about porn stars and playmates. So maybe it shouldnt have been a surprise when the world-famous symbol of the bow-tied Playboy bunny was beamed, like a bat signal, on a building in downtown Washington on Saturday night for the White House Correspondents Association Dinner.

title: Sprint and T-Mobile Try Again, but Antitrust Hurdles Remain the Same
description: Several years ago, Sprints largest shareholder, SoftBank, quietly approached two of the nations top regulators with a question: If Sprint were to merge with T-Mobile, would the government approve it?

title: Russians Protest Government Effort to Block Telegram App
description: Thousands of Russians are taking a bold stand against the Kremlins efforts to block the popular encrypted messaging service, which refused to give the state access to users messages.

title: They Want to Block Our Future: Thousands Protest Russias Internet Censorship
description: MOSCOW  A demonstration in Moscow against the Russian governments effort to block the messaging app Telegram quickly morphed on Monday into a protest against President Vladimir V. Putin, with thousands of participants chanting against the Kremlins increasingly restrictive bent.

title: Bright Lights, Big Sofas
description: Its spring! (Sort of.) A more reliable sign than the balky weather is the Kips Bay Decorator Show House, opening Tuesday in an Upper East Side brownstone. Now in its 46th year, the show house is always a spectacle, a three-dimensional tour into the lives of the 1 percent. (The townhouse is for sale for $51 million.) This year, 22 designers are spread out over seven levels and about 15,000 square feet.

title: Robert E. Rubin: Philosophy Prepared Me for a Career in Finance and Government
description: When I arrived at Harvard in 1956 as a freshman, I felt overwhelmed academically. Unlike many of my classmates who had gone to rigorous private schools, I graduated from a Florida public school that in those days rarely sent kids to elite colleges in the North. Even after four years of high school French, I couldnt pass the exam to get out of the entry-level class at Harvard. In math, I was relegated to the remedial course.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Cases on Death Penalty and Class Actions
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court added three cases to its docket on Monday, agreeing to hear disputes about lethal injections, class-action settlements and arbitration.

title: Missing Mexicans Case Shines Light on Militarys Role in Drug War
description: MEXICO CITY  On a cold night in December 2009, three relatives in the Mexican state of Chihuahua were taken away by a group of armed men in military uniforms and were never seen again.

title: Kabul, Netanyahu, North Korea: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: How to Wear Springs Most Inventive New Makeup
description: If theres a universal truth to be drawn from the current makeup landscape, its that more is more. So many new products crowd the market that even a beauty hound can become boggled. Sift through them, though, and there are creative new options well worth your attention. Textures, in particular, have become more inventive. Below, a primer on some of the newest and some tips on how to use them.

title: Stormy Daniels Files Defamation Lawsuit Against Donald Trump
description: Lawyers for the pornographic film star Stephanie Clifford filed a defamation lawsuit against President Trump on Monday, based on statements he made on Twitter two weeks ago that questioned her credibility.

title: Israel Says Secret Files Detail Irans Nuclear Subterfuge
description: JERUSALEM  Revealing a huge archive of stolen Iranian nuclear plans, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel accused Iran on Monday of lying for years about its efforts to build a nuclear weapon.

title: Show Us Your Designs for the Royal Wedding Dress
description: If you have an eye for design, send us a sketch of the dress you would make for Meghan Markle. Some submissions may be selected for publication.

title: Stanley Kubrick: Before He Wrote Scripts, He Took Photos
description: Starting in 1945, when he was 17 and living in the Bronx, Stanley Kubrick worked as a New York-based photographer for Look magazine. He joined the staff full time in October 1946, and he quit in August 1950. By the time I was 21 I had four years of seeing how things worked in the world, Kubrick told an interviewer in 1972. I think if I had gone to college I would never have been a director.

title: Attack Kills American Service Member in Eastern Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  An attack on Monday in eastern Afghanistan killed one American service member and wounded another in the second United States military combat death this year in the enduring war.

title: Op-Docs: Information for Filmmakers
description: What is Op-Docs?

title: New York Times Metro Editor Resigns, Citing Mistakes
description: The New York Times announced on Monday that Wendell Jamieson, the newspapers metro editor, had resigned after an internal investigation but did not specify the reason for his departure.

title: Steven Marcus, Columbia Scholar and Literary Critic, Dies at 89
description: Steven Marcus, a Columbia College professor who transformed literary criticism into a lens on history and society by revealing a subculture of Victorian pornography and psychoanalyzing characters in Charles Dickenss novels, died on April 25 in a Manhattan hospital. He was 89.

title: Investment Boom From Trumps Tax Cut Has Yet to Appear
description: After years of costly layoffs and plant closings, things are looking up for the heavy-machinery giant Caterpillar, which forecasts solid global sales growth and increased demand this year. Yet despite the corporate investment incentives at the center of President Trumps tax overhaul, the companys executives have no plans to supercharge investment or expansion.

title: Theres No Reason to Apologize for Muslim Ban Remarks, Trump Says
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump said on Monday that he would not apologize for campaign statements calling for a Muslim ban, appearing to undercut an assertion at a Supreme Court argument last week from Solicitor General Noel J. Francisco. In defending Mr. Trumps efforts to restrict travel from several predominantly Muslim countries, Mr. Francisco said that the president had already disavowed the statements.

title: French Museum Discovers More Than Half Its Collection Is Fake
description: PARIS  One painting included a castle tower that had been built in the late 1950s. But the artist who supposedly painted it, tienne Terrus, died in 1922.

title: Ireland Investigates Cervical Cancer Screening Scandal
description: DUBLIN  The Irish government announced on Monday that it was opening an official inquiry and setting up phone help lines and emergency testing after it emerged that a publicly funded smear test program had mistakenly cleared at least 208 women who later received diagnoses of cervical cancer.

title: Abbas: A Lens on the World
description: Revolution in Iran, the Troubles in Belfast, the Rumble in the Jungle in Zaire: The Magnum photographer Abbas covered them all and more.

title: Abbas Attar, Who Photographed Irans Revolution, Dies at 74
description: Abbas Attar, an Iranian-born photographer who documented cataclysmic events throughout the world, including the Iranian revolution, and developed a particular interest in the role of religion in them, died on Wednesday in Paris. He was 74.

title: Netanyahu, Stormy Daniels, N.B.A.: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: God Save the Q
description: Dear Diary:

title: ICE Leader, Advocate of Tough Trump Immigration Policies, Will Retire
description: WASHINGTON  Thomas D. Homan, the acting director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, said on Monday that he would retire from the deportation agency in June, after more than a year of pushing President Trumps controversial plans to remove thousands of undocumented immigrants from the United States.

title: Judge Permits Government to Appeal DACA Lawsuit
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn gave permission to the government on Monday to appeal his recent decision that allowed two lawsuits seeking to preserve a program that shields some undocumented young adults from deportation to cite President Trumps racially charged language against Latinos.

title: WhatsApp Co-Founder Leaving Facebook Amid User Data Disputes
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Jan Koum, a founder of the messaging app WhatsApp, sold the service to Facebook in 2014, he explained how deeply he cared about the privacy of communication. Growing up in the Soviet Union during the 1980s  when surveillance was a fact of life  had made him realize the importance of being able to speak freely, he wrote.

title: Retired N.B.A. Coach Don Nelson Talks Playoffs, Poker and, Uh, Weed
description: MAUI, Hawaii  Regrets, hes had a few. But say this about Don Nelson, the retired basketball coach: He definitely did it his way.

title: Ashley Judd Sues Harvey Weinstein, Saying He Harmed Her Career
description: LOS ANGELES  Ashley Judd sued Harvey Weinstein on Monday, opening a new legal battlefront for the disgraced film producer by claiming that her career withered because he spread lies about her in Hollywood after she rejected his sexual requests.

title: Mars InSight: NASAs Journey Into the Red Planets Deepest Mysteries
description: NASAs Mars InSight spacecraft, scheduled to launch on Saturday, is headed to one of the most boring places on the red planet.

title: Augmented Reality: Explore InSight, NASAs Latest Mission to Mars
description: The InSight spacecraft is heading to Mars to listen for marsquakes and study the planets structure.

title: For Second Time in a Week, Trump Weighs In on World Cup Bidding
description: For the second time in a week, President Trump on Monday urged other countries to support the North American bid to host the 2026 World Cup and again implied there might be consequences for those who did not. The comments, made during a news conference in the Rose Garden, raised new questions about whether Mr. Trumps input constitutes political interference in the bidding process, which could jeopardize the joint bid by the United States, Mexico and Canada.

title: Hows That Tax Cut Working Out?
description: So far, Donald Trump and his allies in Congress have achieved one and only one major legislative victory: passing a large tax cut, mainly aimed at corporations and business owners. The tax cuts proponents promised that it would lead to a dramatic acceleration of economic growth and produce big gains in wages; they hoped that it would also yield big political dividends for the midterm elections.

title: U.S. Lets a Few Members of a Migrant Caravan Apply for Asylum
description: TIJUANA, Mexico  Several members of the Latin American migrant caravan that has enraged President Trump were allowed to step onto United States territory to apply for asylum late Monday, ending a border standoff that had lasted more than a day and marking the beginning of the final chapter of the groups monthlong odyssey.

title: The Loving Place for Children That Assumes Beauty
description: COMO, Italy  Some of the people who do the most good have a willingness to be radically changed. They are sensitive to the problems around them, which a lot of us are, but they are also willing to transform their lives to address them, which a lot of us dont consider. I met many such people at a place here in northern Italy called Cometa.

title: A Refugee Caravan is Hoping for Asylum in the U.S. How Are These Cases Decided?
description: Russian ballet dancers, Cuban baseball players and Chinese political dissidents. These are the kind of people fleeing persecution in their homelands who typically won asylum in the United States over the years.

title: Would AT&Ts Time Warner Deal Help or Hurt Consumers? Judge Will Now Decide
description: WASHINGTON  Lawyers faced off over the future of AT&Ts $85.4 billion blockbuster merger with Time Warner for a final time in a courtroom on Monday, sparring over what the deal would mean to consumers.

title: What Vulgar Remarks? Trump and Buhari, Nigerias Leader, Avoid Clash
description: WASHINGTON  In January, when word got out that President Trump had disparaged African nations in vulgar terms during an Oval Office rant about immigration policy, his remarks were met with alarm and outrage by leaders and others on the continent.

title: A True Treasure Is Reduced to Rubble in Smithtown
description: SMITHTOWN, N.Y.  Rosemary Culhane remembers the splendor of the old house.

title: Gerson Leiber, 96, Dies; Artist Created Museum With Designer Wife
description: Gerson Leiber, an American modernist painter whose ambitions were stunted until he attended art school in Budapest, where he had served in the Army during World War II, died on Saturday at his home in Springs, N.Y., a hamlet in East Hampton. He was 96.

title: The Implausible Promises of a T-Mobile-Sprint Merger
description: T-Mobile and Sprint are making some big promises to sell their proposed $26.5 billion merger. They assert that the merger  which would reduce the number of national wireless companies from four to three  would give them the scale they need to build a high-capacity wireless network with 5G, or fifth-generation, technology. If the Federal Communications Commission and the Department of Justice approve the deal, T-Mobile and Sprint say, the company wont raise prices and it will hire more people, rather than reduce the work force, which is more often the case in such mergers. And they say all this will be done while costs are cut by $6 billion a year and profits rise substantially.

title: Facebooks Privacy Changes Leave Developers Steaming
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For years, Cubeyou made a business out of personal data on Facebook. The company had unfettered access to Facebook users information, which it gathered up through quizzes and later sold as reports to clients.

title: Truth Has Stopped Mattering in the Russia Investigation
description: On Friday, Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee released a report based on their cursory investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. Full of shoddy rationalizations and evasions, it purported to show that Americas intelligence community failed to use proper analytic tradecraft in concluding that Russia wanted to help elect Donald Trump, and that there is no evidence that the Trump campaign colluded with Russia. Its real message was that, for Republicans in Congress determined to protect this president, evidence is irrelevant.

title: Capitals Tom Wilson Tries to Shed Tough Guy Label for a New One: Go-To Guy
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  Washington Capitals forward Tom Wilson wore the label like a tattoo during his first four N.H.L. seasons: a fourth-line enforcer who often committed bad penalties with devastating hits.

title: Meet the Schlapps, Washingtons Trump-Era It Couple
description: WASHINGTON  Matt Schlapp, the pro-Trump chairman of the American Conservative Union, had a remarkable on-air clash not long ago with his old friend Michael Steele, an anti-Trump former chairman of the Republican National Committee.

title: It Took 17 Years: Freelancers Receive $9 Million in Copyright Suit
description: Seventeen years after nearly 3,000 freelance journalists filed a class-action lawsuit claiming copyright infringement by some of the countrys biggest publishers, the checks are finally in the mail.

title: Did Michelle Wolf Kill the White House Correspondents Dinner?
description: As the power elite of Washington filed out of the White House Correspondents Association dinner on Saturday, chattering about the rough-and-tumble set by the comedian Michelle Wolf, the White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, was invited to pose for a portrait with her fellow honorees on the dais.
